citation.article-title: Legionella pneumophila serogroup Lansing 3 isolated from a patient with fatal pneumonia, and descriptions of L. pneumophila subsp. pneumophila subsp. nov., L. pneumophila subsp. fraseri subsp. nov., and L. pneumophila subsp. pascullei subsp. nov.

p.s: Emended description of Legionella pneumophila (Brenner, Steigerwalt, and McDade 1979)
Legionella pneumophila (pneu.mo'phi.la; Greek noun pneumo, lung; Greek adjective, philos, loving; M.L. adjective, pneumophila, lung loving)
Legionella pneumophila is a gram-negative, aerobic, non-spore-forming, nonencapsulated, non-acid-fast rod, 0.3 to 0.9 μm wide and 2 to 20 μm or more long.
It is motile by one or more straight or curved polar or lateral flagella; occasional strains are nonmotile.
L-Cysteine hydrochloride and iron salts are required for growth.
It is weakly oxidase positive or negative.
It is catalase positive, and gelatin is liquefied.
Tests for nitrate reduction, urease, and blue-white or red autofluorescence are negative.
It is chemoorganotrophic, using amino acids as carbon and energy sources.
Carbohydrates are neither fermented nor oxidized.
A brown, diffusible pigment is formed in media containing tyrosine.
It produces β-lactamase and contains granules that stain with Sudan black B.
Branched-chain fatty acids predominate in the cell wall.
It contains major amounts of ubiquinones with more than 10 isoprene units in the side chain.
Most strains hydrolyze hippurate.
It has been isolated from human lung, sputum, and blood and from water and is the major causative agent of legionellosis.
G+C content is 38 to 41 mol%.
The type strain is Philadelphia 1 (ATCC 33152) isolated from human lung tissue (G+C content, 39 mol%).
